Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cell Excretion, a Novel Mechanism of Cell Clearance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Genetically programmed forms of cell death occur at a high rate throughout life in many animal tissues, necessitating rapid clearance of the resulting cell corpses to preserve tissue homeostasis. In the canonical cell clearance mechanism, remnants of apoptotic cells are engulfed by phagocytic cells and degraded in the lysosome. However, recent work has revealed that alternative forms of cell clearance are also important for meatazoan development and physiology. The objective of this proposal is to characterize one such novel process in the planarian flatworm Schmidtea mediterranea. The proposed experiments will address the hypothesis that light exposure triggers pigment cell death, but that the resulting corpses are redistributed to the gut and excreted, instead of being subjected to lysosomal degradation. Student researchers will gain valuable experience in current techniques, including RNA interference and confocal microscopy, developing skills that prepare them for scientific careers and/or graduate programs in the biological sciences. The work associated with this award will therefore augment the state of New Hampshire's efforts to expand the pipeline for future STEM professionals, a central goal of the state EPSCoR program.

Preliminary data produced by the PI show that prolonged exposure to intense visible light induces complete bodily depigmentation in adult planarians and that this is associated with excretion of large amounts of heavily pigmented material from the gut. By revealing the cellular mechanisms underlying this response, the research component of this project is likely to provide new insight into how self-renewing adult tissues clear dead or damaged cells. Histologic analyses will be combined with a double-labeling approach incorporating TUNEL and fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to characterize the cellular mechanisms of a light-induced depigmentation response that appears to result from selective elimination of pigment cells. The research project will significantly advance our understanding of metazoan tissue homeostasis by complementing our existing knowledge of the canonical apoptotic cell clearance pathway. Results from the study will be disseminated through scientific conference presentations and by publication in peer-reviewed journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project originated with an unexpected discovery in a general education course for non-science majors. Students conducting science fair-style experiments on planarians, flatworms with the remarkable ability to regenerate lost body parts, found that prolonged exposure to bright light resulted in complete loss of the animals’ normal, brown body color. Our preliminary observations led us to hypothesize this response is due to rapid elimination of the pigment cells in the skin. Curiously, these cells appear to be redistributed to the gut and excreted, a fate not previously described for dying cells in other organisms. In addition to providing further support for this model, our work on this project also yielded surprising insight into the initial trigger for pigment cell death. Specifically, we found that planarian pigment cells generate porphyrins, ring-shaped molecules that can have harmful effects when they react with oxygen in the presence of light. Inhibition of porphyrin production blocked light-induced pigment cell loss. Porphyrins also accumulate in the skin of humans suffering from rare, but sometimes life-threating light-sensitivity disorders called porphyrias. Our findings have established a new animal model for research on the basic science of porphyrins and how they sensitize cells to light, as well as evidence for a novel means of clearing damaged cells from animal tissues.

In addition to the scientific outcomes of the project, our work had broader impacts in two major areas. First, local high school students were engaged in original research projects on planarians, facilitating the development of critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Second, undergraduate students received training in basic science research, preparing them for entry into STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) career paths. Indeed, students who participated in this project have gone on to enter graduate programs or positions in academia or industry after completing their degrees. Thus, our undergraduate research program is contributing to workforce development in the state of New Hampshire and promoting continued growth of the regional STEM economy.
